A BlOGRAPHICAI, AND BlBWOGRAPHICAI, Summary ok the World's Most Emi- nent Authors, inci,uding the Choicest Extracts and Master. pieces from their writings .-. Carefully Revised and Arranged by a Corps of the Most Capable Scholars EDITOR-IN-CHIEF JfiJin Clark RIdpath, A.M., LLD. Editor of" The Arena," Author of" Ridpath's History of the United States," " Encyclo- pedia of Universal History," "Great Races of Mankind," etc., etc. 22Mtion be %\\xc TWENTY-FIVE VOLUMES Vol. XXV FIFTH AVENUE LIBRARY SOCIETY NEW YORK CrOPYRIOHT, 1899 Br THE ©LOBE PUBLISHING COMPANY INTRODUCTION I have come to regard a book as curtailed of half its value If it has not a pretty full index.— Binney. For a work of such wide scope as The Library of Universal Literature a comprehensive index is in- dispensable. Though the work is encyclopedic in character, and for this reason arranged alphabetically for convenient reference to authors, it is more than an encyclopedia of writers. Were the articles limited to biographies this alphabetical arrangement would answer the purpose of the most exacting student. But in the compilation of this work the editor has done more. He has classified the writers according to their works, made selections from their best books, and culled opinions from able contemporary and subsequent critics to show their relative merits. Many who are known to the world in general as romancists have, on the close scrutiny to which they have been subjected during the compilation of this work, been found to have produced poetry, critical essays, or contributions to science or history which might have made them famous in those lines had not their greater works overshadowed others of real merit. Many a noted philosopher might be considered a great wit could we but lose sight of his sage sayings. In classifying the various authors it has therefore been found necessary frequently to place the same name under several headings, so the inquirev-' may not be at a loss to find the fi«vme of a poet under the d INTRODUCTION^ proper classification, even though he also be known as a novelist. This section of the index will be found of great value to anyone searching for writers in the several departments of literature. The collection of excerpts from the principal works of the authors represented would lose more than half its value without being indexed. It will be found by reference to this index that many subjects are treated of by different authors in different parts of the work, and where one might scarcely expect to find them with- out such reference. The selections also comprise much biographical matter and critical opinions of authors not found in the regular alphabetical order. For the purpose of compiling theses, essays or sermons, or for strengthening one's own opinions by getting the matured thoughts of others on the same questions, it will be readily seen that this section of the index ii invaluable. Though the title of each extract has been written with a view to suggesting the tenor of the article, it frequently transpires that the heading (often the author's own and selected at his caprice) indicates neither the character of the writing nor the subject treated. The present editor thought it expedient therefore to further set forth the titles to the extracts in an Analytical Index, wherein the selections are grouped under several general headings, to indicate cither the subject-matter or the rhetorical character of the writings. In making this analysis of the selec- tions, the poetry, in which the work is exceptionally rich, has been grouped into verses suitable for quota- tion on various occasions and on the subjects usually sung of by the bard, such as " Love," " Patriotism," •*Thc Sea," "Death," etc. It is hoped the need of INTRODUCTIOM % ready reference to appropriate quotations will be filled by this section of the Index. The Index of Bibliography is a compendium of the world's literature. What studious reader has not felt the necessity of such a work ! It is evident that to read all the works on one subject (unless it be a trifling one) is impossible, even for a specialist. But by reference to this Bibliographical Index the choice of several may be made, and possibly one by an author acknowledged to be the master in his line. Description of the Index is not complete without a brief reference to the synchronistic charts. As chronology is the framework of history, so synchro- nology is the skeleton of literature. The value of many a book is determined by the circumstances under which it was written. A careful study of these tables will disclose the gradual unrolling of the scroll of literature in the light of civil and political history, as well as the effect on literature of the world's progress.
